headline: Sanofi’s Dengue Vaccine Gets FDA Approval
summary: Sanofi dengue vaccine was approved in the U.S., the first treatment cleared by American regulators to protect against the mosquito-borne viral infection.

headline: HPS Investment Partners to Loan New Sears $800 Million
summary: Edward Lampert’s new Sears has lined up an $800 million loan from a group of lenders led by HPS Investment Partners to keep its remaining stores up and running, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: White House, Security Officials Discuss Venezuela Response
summary: The White House is convening a meeting of top national-security officials to discuss its next steps in the crisis in Venezuela, President Trump’s national security adviser said.

headline: Tiger Woods to Visit White House
summary: Tiger Woods is scheduled to visit the White House next week to meet with President Trump following his dramatic win at the Masters, a person familiar with the plans said.

headline: Amazon Targets Middle East With Arabic Website
summary: Amazon is diving deeper into the Middle East, launching the first Arabic-language site under its own brand in a country better known for over-the-top malls: the U.A.E.

headline: Ex-CIA Officer Pleads Guilty to Efforts to Supply China With Classified Information
summary: A former CIA officer pleaded guilty to conspiring to provide classified information to China, as the U.S. fights what officials describe as a widening campaign by China to shake loose government secrets.

headline: XPO Logistics Earnings Slide in Weaker Freight Market
summary: The Greenwich, Conn.-based logistics provider’s adjusted diluted earnings per share declined in the first quarter, beating expectations as revenue fell back in a weakening North American freight market and the company coped with the loss of business from Amazon.com Inc.

headline: uBiome CEOs Go on Leave After FBI Search
summary: The co-chief executives of uBiome, Jessica Richman and Zac Apte, are on leave in the wake of a search of the lab-test startup’s offices by the FBI.

headline: A Real Attorney General
summary: Bill Barr gets smeared for refusing to duck and cover like Loretta Lynch.

headline: House Suspends Deadline for Banks to Hand Over Trump Documents
summary: The House of Representatives agreed to suspend its deadline for Deutsche Bank and Capital One to turn over financial documents related to President Trump and his family until a court settles their effort to block the subpoenas.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Choice ‘Escalator’
summary: The Legislature moves to expand credits for education scholarships.

headline: Starbucks Recalls Bodum Coffee Presses
summary: Starbucks is voluntarily recalling a coffee press it sold for more than two years after receiving reports about it breaking during use, causing cuts and puncture wounds.

headline: Honey, We Shrunk the Ex-Im Bank
summary: And nobody outside Washington noticed.

headline: New York Chancellor Affirms Push to End Elite-Schools Test
summary: The chancellor of New York City schools testified for more than two hours at a City Council hearing, defending the view that the admissions test for eight elite high schools must be abolished.

headline: A Case for Lower Rates Still Lurks
summary: Inflation could start to reflect new technology, business models and statistical methods. If that happens, the case for lowering rates could become overwhelming.

headline: CME Group Posts 17% Drop in Profit
summary: CME Group, the Chicago-based exchange giant, reported that revenue rose but earnings dropped during a quarter of lower volatility in markets.

headline: Eventbrite Shares Plunge After Quarterly Loss, Weak Forecast
summary: Eventbrite shares fell about 29% during after-hours trading Wednesday after the event-ticketing company posted a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and gave a disappointing forecast.

headline: Trump Administration Now Urges Court to Strike Down Entire Health Law
summary: The Trump administration urged a federal appeals court Wednesday to strike down the entire Affordable Care Act, presenting for the first time its new position opposing the entirety of the Obama-era health law.

headline: Qualcomm to Get at Least $4.5 Billion in Apple Settlement
summary: Qualcomm will receive at least $4.5 billion as part of a legal settlement with Apple that ended more than two years of wrangling over the chip maker’s patent-licensing fees.

headline: China Cracks Down in Asia’s Once Freest City
summary: The attack on political freedom in Hong Kong could sap the vitality that made it the world’s envy.

headline: ‘Medicare for All’ Isn’t Medicare
summary: Democrats mislead voters by appropriating the name of a popular program they actually seek to abolish.

headline: The Afghan Endgame Has Become Surreal
summary: American negotiators are coddling the Taliban while declaring an allied official persona non grata.

headline: The Complicated Truth About Vaccines
summary: They can appear to be the proximate cause of a condition when they have nothing to do with the ultimate cause.

headline: UC Berkeley’s Emi Nakamura Wins John Bates Clark Medal
summary: Emi Nakamura, a University of California at Berkeley professor who has used novel data sources to understand how the economy works in practice, is this year’s recipient of the most prestigious award for young economists.

headline: ‘The Adjunct Underclass’ Review: Teachable Moments
summary: College teaching has become a pickup job, like driving for Uber, for small stipends and little or no guarantee of permanence.

headline: MetLife Weathers Tough Insurance Market as Prudential Stumbles
summary: The two largest publicly traded U.S. life-insurance companies—MetLife and Prudential Financial—posted divergent earnings as one was able to overcome a tough market in the first quarter and the other wasn’t.

headline: Joe Biden’s Last Ride
summary: Karl Marx himself might think the booming U.S. labor market looks pretty darn good.

headline: Please, Take Socialism Seriously
summary: The debate raises basic moral questions we’ve long ignored.

headline: Can Dems Resist the Urge to Impeach?
summary: That would be wise, but Trump-hating House members may lack the self-restraint.

headline: NYSE Owner Bets on Mortgage Digitization
summary: Intercontinental Exchange is acquiring a firm that facilitates electronic processing of mortgage records.

headline: Student Loan Firm Fined For Failing to Make Adjustments
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau imposed a $3.9 million fine on Conduent Education Services, alleging that it failed to take required steps to ease the burden on borrowers facing difficulty repaying their loans.

headline: Gold Slips as Fed Wraps Policy Meeting
summary: Gold prices fell Wednesday, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled the central bank was unlikely to cut rates in coming months.

headline: Akamai Bets on ‘Zero Trust’ Approach to Security
summary: Akamai Technologies aims to expand its security business, in part by convincing companies that building walls around information-technology systems will no longer keep hackers, bots and malware out.

headline: White House Rejects House Panel’s Request for Security-Clearance Documents
summary: The White House notified the House Oversight Committee that it wouldn’t comply with the panel’s requests for documents related to the Trump administration’s handling of security clearances, escalating a standoff.

headline: Trump Administration Calls for $4.5 Billion to Address Crisis at Border
summary: The Trump administration requested $4.5 billion from Congress to respond to the growing surge of migrants at the southern border, deepening a fight with Democrats over a crisis that both sides accuse the other of exacerbating.

headline: New Immersive Show Bills Itself as ‘Sleep No More’ for Kids
summary: “Pip’s Island” is billed as “an immersive entertainment adventure” geared for the grade school-and-younger set.

headline: U.S. Dollar Strengthens After Powell Suggests Soft Inflation Is Transitory
summary: The WSJ Dollar Index declined 0.2% after the Institute for Supply Management said its manufacturing index fell to 52.8 in April from 55.3 during the previous month.

headline: Online Ad Fraud Is Down, Study Finds—or at Least It’s Harder to Detect
summary: Marketers are expected to waste $5.8 billion this year on buying online ads that will be viewed by bots instead of humans—an 11% decline from the amount estimated to have been lost to fraud in 2017.

headline: U.S. Navy Plans to Extend Its Reach in the Arctic
summary: The Navy and Marine Corps are deepening their commitments to Arctic security and to operations in Alaska.

headline: Iran Vows to Resist U.S. Oil Ban as Exports Fall
summary: A U.S. oil ban won’t stop Iran from selling its crude, the country’s oil minister said, even as new signs emerged that Tehran’s crude exports are heading toward a collapse.

headline: Sri Lanka Identifies All Nine Easter Bombers
summary: The eight men and one woman who detonated bombs on Easter Sunday, killing themselves and more than 250 others, were a collection of Islamist radicals including a quiet truck driver and a foreign-educated engineer.

headline: Rebuilding Notre Dame: Not so Fast
summary: Bad enough that the restoration is now in the hands of bureaucrats, but it should not fall victim to an artificially rushed schedule or the whims of celebrity architects.

headline: New York City Jail Inmates Can Now Make Free Phone Calls
summary: All inmates being held in New York City jails will no longer have to pay a fee to make a phone call, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Wednesday.

headline: Midwest City’s Downtown Floods in First Failure of Plan to Hold Back Mississippi River
summary: After a temporary flood barrier gave way in Davenport, Iowa, several blocks of downtown sat underwater in the first major failure of the city’s uncommon flood-fighting strategy.

headline: Justice Department Provides Blueprint for Companies on Compliance
summary: The Justice Department for years has weighed the strength of compliance programs as a factor when deciding whether to bring charges against a company or appoint an independent monitor. This week, prosecutors stepped up their emphasis.

headline: Stocks Decline as Fed Stays Patient on Rates
summary: Stocks fell after the Fed left interest rates unchanged and reiterated it will stay patient despite a recent patch of soft inflation.

headline: Oil Falls on Increasing Supply
summary: Oil prices declined after government data showed a larger-than-expected increase in U.S. stockpiles.

headline: America Isn’t Doomed to Follow the Left Coast
summary: Given that California’s progressive thrust is about 15 years behind Europe’s, one can look at France or Germany circa 1994 (assuming the U.S. is 10 years into its catch-up phase with California) for a glimpse into America’s future.

headline: Joe Biden Is No Threat to President Trump
summary: You say that: “With a unifying message, Mr. Biden could be a real threat in 2020.” Joe Biden doesn’t have one. His message is the same as Hillary Clinton’s in 2016: I hate Trump. How’d that work out for her?

headline: The ACA Need Not Have Upended All Health Care
summary: The only ones using ObamaCare now are the poor and those with new or chronic pre-existing conditions, who get massive subsidies. Why President Obama had to upend all of health care just to address the needs of these two underserved groups remains a mystery.

headline: U.S. Needs a Private-Public Partnership on 5G Research
summary: President Trump should convene a meeting of tech CEOs and government R&D entities like Darpa and challenge them to build the strategy and team to beat global challengers in the 5G space.

headline: America’s History Censors Imitate ISIS in Ignorance
summary: ISIS destroyed priceless antiquities and cultural heritage sites in the Middle East because they conflicted with ISIS’s ideological and historical perspectives. Is there really any difference with that and what is generally occurring today in San Francisco?

headline: U.S. Treasury Yields Edge Higher After Fed Decision
summary: Treasury yields initially fell after the Federal Reserve held rates steady and highlighted slowing inflation, but then moved higher amid comments from Fed Chairman Jerome Powell.

headline: U.S. Natural-Gas Inventories Expected to Rise
summary: Analysts expect government data to show that natural-gas storage levels rose by 112 billion cubic feet during the latest week, which would be more than the average for this time of year.

headline: Roundup Sellers Boost Ads as Lawsuits Mount
summary: Bayer and Scotts Miracle-Gro have spent millions of dollars this year on expanded marketing for the weedkiller Roundup, Scotts executives said. Thousands of people say it caused their cancer.

headline: The Fed’s Inflation Problem
summary: A first-quarter downdraft has sent inflation back below the Federal Reserve’s 2% target. But even if it persists, low inflation might not count as a reason to cut rates.

headline: U.K.’s May Fires Defense Secretary Over Huawei Leak
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May fired Defense Secretary Gavin Williamson, saying he leaked sensitive information surrounding a review into the use of equipment from China’s Huawei Technologies Co. in the U.K.’s telecoms network.

headline: U.N. Designates Pakistani as Terrorist After China Acquiesces
summary: The leader of a Pakistani-based Islamist group that India blames for at least two terrorist attacks was placed by the United Nations Security Council on a list of global terrorists subject to sanctions.

headline: Florida Lawmakers Pass Bill Allowing Armed Teachers
summary: The Florida House of Representatives passed a school-security bill allowing teachers to be armed and will send the legislation to Gov. Ron DeSantis, who is expected to sign it into law.

headline: Bill Would Deny U.S. Pensions to Convicted Child Molesters
summary: A U.S. senator is seeking to ban convicted child molesters from receiving government pensions after a U.S. Indian Health Service doctor was revealed to be drawing a six-figure retirement income following his conviction for sexually abusing patients.

headline: Math Wizard Elwyn Berlekamp Helped Bring Sharp Images From Outer Space
summary: Berkeley professor Elwyn Berlekamp enhanced digital communications, studied game theory and ran a hedge fund.

headline: Fed Again Lowers Interest on Excess Reserves Rate, Moving to 2.35%
summary: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday lowered a key interest rate to bolster its control over monetary policy, a technical adjustment that didn’t represent a shift in its efforts to influence overall economic growth.

headline: Caster Semenya Loses Challenge to Rule on Testosterone Levels
summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sport dismissed Olympic champion Caster Semenya’s challenge to a new rule that sought to regulate accepted testosterone levels for female athletes competing in mid-distance running events.

headline: Where the Land O’Lakes Leader Turns for Challenges With ‘People Moments’
summary: One of around two dozen female CEOs of a Fortune 500 company, Land O’Lakes’ Beth Ford says she learned early in her career to watch and learn from the behavior of “folks who are excellent at what they do,” as well as taking note of people she “didn’t want to behave like.”

headline: Disney Promotes Studio Executive Amid Box-Office Boom
summary: Walt Disney said it is shuffling the executive ranks at its film operation, elevating studio President Alan Bergman to help oversee a division behind Hollywood’s biggest hits.

headline: Restaurant Chain Kona Grill Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Kona Grill has filed for bankruptcy, saying a stock buyback and the decision to double its number of restaurants just as customer traffic was starting to fall have hurt its liquidity.

headline: For Lower-Paid Workers, the Robot Overlords Have Arrived

headline: Canada Moves to Mitigate Fallout From China Canola Ban
summary: Canada extended financial help to canola-seed producers affected by China’s import ban, part of an effort to dull the impacts of China’s retaliation for the arrest of a Huawei executive.

headline: Photos: Venezuela Opposition Tries to Gain Momentum
summary: Scenes from Caracas after opposition leader Juan Guaidó appeared with members of the military and called for mass demonstrations

headline: Royal Caribbean Raises Revenue Outlook on Strong Cruise Bookings
summary: Royal Caribbean expects to earn even more money per passenger this year due to strong demand for cruises and higher booking prices. The cruise-ship operator said first-quarter profit rose 14%.

headline: CVS Eases Concerns About Aetna Deal
summary: CVS Health delivered stronger-than-expected results in its first quarter as a combined health-care company, taking a step toward selling skeptical investors on its acquisition of Aetna.

headline: Fossil Points to a Vanished Human Species in Himalayas
summary: A fossil jaw discovered in Himalayan highlands of Tibet shows the vanished human species called the Denisovans lived at an altitude that would leave many people today starved for oxygen.

headline: Mozambique Deal Haunts Resurgent Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse faces rising international pressure to forgive loans the bank made to Mozambican companies engaged in an alleged complex fraud, and potentially, to pay damages to victims.

headline: Sell in May and…Never Mind
summary: This isn’t one of those years to sell stocks in May, seasonal patterns notwithstanding.

summary: Acid-colored clothing needn’t be relegated to Malibu Barbie and Kim Kardashian West. When used judiciously, megawatt shades can enliven even quiet wardrobes.

headline: U.S. Factory Activity Slows in April
summary: U.S. factory activity slowed in April, with the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index falling to 52.8, amid concerns over trade tensions and delays at the U.S.-Mexico border.

headline: ‘Beetlejuice’ Review: Better Off Dead
summary: The latest entry in the screen-to-stage trend is a ghoulish, overlong adaptation of a cult classic.

headline: Greece’s Slow Justice Lets Fascist Party Prosper
summary: The trial of Golden Dawn has stalled in a case that highlights a dysfunctional Greek justice system that also harms the country in many other ways.

headline: Molly Ringwald’s Surprising Career Path: Novel Translator
summary: She’s still acting—see her on soapy hit Riverdale—but the former teen icon has another skill up her sleeve: French translator. She talks about her first novel translation, hitting shelves this week.

headline: U.K. Conservatives Steer Clear of Brexit Ahead of Elections
summary: With Brexit delayed possibly until the end of October, the European Parliament election, which follows local-council votes the Conservatives are expected to lose, has become a symbol for many traditional ruling-party voters of Prime Minister Theresa May’s failure to deliver.

headline: The Top 5 Things You Don’t Want to Miss at Frieze New York
summary: The fair brings together a compelling mix of established and emerging artists—and Frieze-goers can even become portrait subjects themselves.

headline: A Long-Distance Renovation in a Gentrifying Piece of London
summary: Thanks to 3-D imaging, email and lots of digital photos, this family oversaw a complete renovation of their home in Peckham while living in Budapest

headline: A Long-Distance Renovation in a Gentrifying Piece of London
summary: Thanks to 3-D imaging, email and lots of digital photos, this family oversaw a complete renovation of their home in Peckham while living in Budapest.

headline: CEOs in Health Care Discuss Challenges of Artificial Intelligence
summary: Tech is reshaping pharmaceutical research, opioid-addiction treatment and other areas in health care, but change hasn’t been as fast or dramatic as some hoped, industry leaders said at The Wall Street Journal Health Forum.

headline: CVS Shares Are on the Mend
summary: Health-care and insurance giant CVS Health has seen its share price punished by political and competitive concerns, but making a bet on the status quo is attractive for investors who can wait.

headline: Congestion Pricing Could Give Lift to Some Home Values
summary: Planned fees aimed at easing traffic in Manhattan will likely edge up residential prices in the targeted zone, study shows, but it may be a bumpy ride for other properties.

headline: Ronan Farrow Scoops Up Lower East Side Penthouse for $5.65 Million
summary: The journalist is known for his work exposing sexual harassment allegations against former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein.

headline: Clorox’s Turn to Leave a Mess in Consumer Goods Business
summary: Clorox shares are lagging peers like Procter & Gamble, but the entire household goods industry is facing challenges.

summary: New York’s MTA is clawing its way out of a looming fiscal crisis by raising fares, securing new sources of revenue and reorganizing operations. Now, it has the chance to cut into its biggest operating cost: labor.

headline: Once a Carnegie Library, Now a Historic Home
summary: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, this restored Rockport, Mass., home was the town library for 90 years. It is on the market for $2.95 million.

headline: Stanford Pushes Executives to Get ‘Touchy Feely’
summary: Stanford University is offering one of its most popular business-school electives to people outside its elite M.B.A. program—a course known widely by its nickname, “Touchy Feely.” The prerequisite? Getting in touch with your emotions.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Rises; Private-Equity Funds Appreciate 5%
summary: Private-equity firm Carlyle Group posted a stronger profit in the latest quarter,  but profits that could be returned to shareholders fell.

headline: WikiLeaks’ Assange Sentenced to 50 Weeks in U.K. Jail
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been sentenced to 50 weeks in jail for breaching bail while awaiting extradition to Sweden on sexual assault accusations in 2012.

headline: Ten Minutes Is All You Need for Nick Hornby’s Latest Creation
summary: Web videos inspired the novelist and screenwriter to create “State of the Union,” a new 10-minute-per-episode series from SundanceTV at the vanguard of experiments in short-form entertainment.

headline: Government Could Run Out of Cash in Second Half, Treasury Says
summary: The government risks not being able to pay its bills on time later this summer or fall unless Congress acts to raise the federal borrowing limit, the Treasury Department said.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Apple, Mondelez, Amgen, AMD, Devon Energy, Blue Apron
summary: Companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday’s session include Apple, Mondelez, Amgen, AMD and Blue Apron.

headline: U.S. Private Sector Surpasses Expectations in April

headline: Karen Elson on Why Modeling Should Have a Chaperone System

summary: Lorne Michaels was a regular. Malcolm Gladwell wrote his books there. Now Keith McNally’s bistro Pastis—a power nexus of the Meatpacking District until its 2014 shuttering—is back.

headline: Post Office Boss Ponders Cutting Mail Delivery to Five Days. Congress Balks.
summary: The head of the U.S. Postal Service floated a new proposal to shore up the agency’s finances: deliver mail five days a week while expanding package delivery to seven.

headline: Google’s Search Business Needs More Answers
summary: Google’s lack of transparency about its core advertising business has taken on an extra cost. Parent company Alphabet lost $60 billion in market value after its quarterly results showed a big revenue shortfall, and investors want explanations.

headline: Cloud Data Specialist Snowflake Picks New Chief
summary: A fast-growing Silicon Valley unicorn is putting a new chief in charge.

headline: Private Equity-Backed Crunch Fitness Weighs Options
summary: Gym chain Crunch Fitness, backed by Angelo, Gordon & Co. and New Evolution Ventures, has hired Citigroup to explore strategic options including a sale, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Stock Markets in Europe Break Records for Calm and Quiet
summary: In Europe, markets have hit their summer lull early. As with markets in the U.S. and elsewhere, this very stability could be a dangerous thing for investors.

headline: Raine Group Leads $70 Million Investment in Ad-Tech Firm VideoAmp
summary: Advertising technology firm VideoAmp Inc. has raised $70 million, suggesting that investors still have confidence in the challenged category.

headline: Qualcomm Profit Will Likely Sag, but All Eyes Are on Apple Windfall
summary: Analysts expect sliding revenue and profit for Qualcomm, but their focus has shifted to the future after the chip maker settled a long-running legal dispute with Apple in mid-April.

headline: Marvel’s Mightiest Zeros: How the Avengers Broke Box Office Records
summary: Everyone in Hollywood knew “Avengers: Endgame” was going to be a hit. But the movie’s ultimate opening-weekend performance crushed all competition past and present with the force of Thor’s hammer.

headline: Upward Move on Key Market Rate Could Bring Fed Response
summary: The Federal Reserve’s tool kit for controlling interest rates is facing a challenge that could prompt changes in the mechanics of how the central bank influences the economy.

headline: As Retiree Health-Care Bills Mount, States Have a Solution: Stop Paying
summary: Local governments across the U.S. are testing how far they can reduce health benefits for their retirees as a way of coping with mounting liabilities and balancing budgets.

headline: Investors Await Clues on Fed’s Rate Pause, Policy Outlook
summary: Federal Reserve officials are poised to leave interest rates unchanged at their two-day meeting ending Wednesday, and the debate could center on what it would take for them to move off the sidelines.

headline: Brands Reach for a Gaming Console
summary: Global brands are dipping a toe into the surreal world of fantasy gaming. The trend shows the need for new tactics to reach young consumers.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: McGraw-Hill to Merge With Rival Textbook Publisher
summary: McGraw-Hill and Cengage plan to merge in a deal that would create the second-largest provider of college textbooks and other higher-education materials in the country.

headline: Venezuela’s Opposition Held Talks With Government on Ousting Maduro
summary: Venezuela’s opposition held secret talks with members of President Nicolás Maduro’s inner circle in recent months in an ill-fated bid to get Mr. Maduro to leave power and install a united interim government.

headline: Holding Rates Steady, Fed Plays Down Worries on Low Inflation
summary: Federal Reserve officials agreed to hold their benchmark interest rate steady and noted some key economic activity had slowed during the first quarter.

headline: Biden Faces Early Heat From the Left
summary: Joe Biden is getting a preview in Iowa this week of what it might take to persuade liberals in his own Democratic Party that he is the right person to defeat President Trump.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Seeks to Expand Uprising Against Maduro
summary: Venezuelans prepared for a second day of demonstrations as opposition leader Juan Guaidó looked to ramp up pressure and spur more members of the military to help drive President Nicolás Maduro’s embattled regime from power.

headline: U.S.-China Trade Deal in Sight
summary: Negotiators made headway on thorny issues in the U.S.-China trade dispute, including access to key markets and how to roll back punitive tariffs, though Chinese subsidies and other sticking points remain.

headline: The Last Time Pelosi and Schumer Cut a Big Infrastructure Deal
summary: The lesson of the 2009 stimulus plan is to expect very little infrastructure.

headline: NJOY, a Once Bankrupt E-Cigarette Maker, Now Seeks $5 Billion Valuation
summary: E-cigarette maker NJOY Holdings is pursuing a funding round that would value the company at as much as $5 billion, and it is trying to interest big tobacco companies looking to take a run at market leader Juul Labs.

headline: Luxury Learning Vacations: Bring Back More Than a Tan
summary: Five spring getaways where you can pick up a few new skills, from polo prowess to a traditional Mexican-cooking chops.

headline: Administration Hires McKinsey to Evaluate Student-Loan Portfolio
summary: The Trump administration has retained private consultants to estimate potential losses in the U.S. government’s $1.45 trillion student-loan portfolio and is weighing selling all or portions of the debt to private investors.

headline: Western Hotel Brands Supercharge African Expansion
summary: The world’s biggest names in hospitality are battling for a slice of one of the world’s fastest-growing markets for hotels: Africa.

headline: It’s Not Allentown: Billy Joel’s Helicopter Commute Irks Long Island Neighbors
summary: A debate over limiting the use of personal helipads is reverberating through a tiny community; ‘I for one don’t want to see Centre Island become East Hampton.’

headline: Bond ETFs Are On Track to Reach $1 Trillion Mark by the End of the Year
summary: The growth is fueled, in part, by investors’ ability to make both tactical and longer-term strategic fixed-income allocations through ETFs.

headline: How Not to Bribe College Basketball Coaches
summary: The alleged bribery of top collegiate players and coaches sounds like a slick operation. But an ongoing federal trial shows that ineptness and low comedy were sprinkled in liberally with the cash.

headline: ‘He Should Go Back to Connecticut.’ Barclays CEO Battles Activist Over Bank’s Future.
summary: Jes Staley’s plans to compete with Wall Street have met resistance from investor Edward Bramson, who owns a sizable stake. A Thursday showdown looms over a board seat.

headline: Venezuelans Clash as Small Group of Troops Joins Guaidó Opposition
summary: Opposition leader Juan Guaidó, flanked by a small group of heavily armed troops outside a military base, called for Venezuelans to protest to overthrow President Nicolás Maduro, setting up a potential armed struggle.

headline: Designer Jeremy Scott Says Fashion Should Lighten Up
summary: Jeremy Scott, the designer who dresses Katy Perry and Miley Cyrus, talks about not taking fashion too seriously and what he might wear to the Met Gala.

headline: Climate Changes as Firms Heed Investors on Social Issues
summary: The largest U.S. companies are beginning to pay heed to the demands of investors focused on environmental and social issues, a shift for shareholders long relegated to the sidelines.

headline: CBS Embraces Strategy of Making Shows for Its Rivals
summary: The company’s recent push to sell content outside its own ecosystem comes as other media giants such as Walt Disney and AT&T’s WarnerMedia focus on making more content primarily for their own platforms.

headline: Auto Dealership Stocks Rally as Firms Pivot From New Vehicles
summary: Stock prices for the nation’s publicly traded dealership groups have rallied in recent months, a sign of Wall Street’s greater confidence in the ability of auto retailers to weather a downturn in the U.S. car market.

headline: The Noisiest Parts of the Plane
summary: Taking a decibel meter onto several different jets finds a difference between the front and the back, and even the window and aisle.

headline: Mueller Objected to Barr’s Summary of Report on Russia
summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller said in a letter to Attorney General William Barr that Mr. Barr’s letter to Congress summarizing his office’s investigation failed to fully capture the context and substance of their probe.

headline: Barr, Democrats Clash Over Mueller Report
summary: Attorney General William Barr criticized Robert Mueller’s decision not to reach a conclusion about whether President Trump obstructed justice during a contentious hearing that laid bare a rift between him and the special counsel over the investigation.
